element_texts.text: Completed

Journal by J. A. Wilkinson   page 1
Across the Plains in 1859
Mar 8th 1859
Started our teams to Pikes Peak from Dowagiac Cass County michigan, our Company consisting of Hungerfords wagon with Jake Hungerford and Orrin Hungerford both old Californians with two other men. 
Also a Mr. Mominees wagon with Mominee (an old French man) and Richard Robinson and Wm Bilderback both under 20 years
Also our own wagon with Uncle Dan Farnham an old Californian. Dan Farnham junior aged 21 and myself Aged 23 years all from Cass County Michigan and all with ox teams
Completed

3
by J. A. Wilkinson
Friday Mar 18th
Heavy storm with rain and snow last night. we have some corn meal and uncle Dan helps to cook, and makes good Johnny cake. It is cold and stormy with bad Roads Forded one small stream traveled 20 miles and camped
Saturday mar 19th
Cold with ground frozen corn 50 cts per bush in the ear as a 2 bush bag full tied up. hay from 5 to 10 dollars per ton. Country Prairie and Roads bad we passed through Ottowa a fine city. Hungerfords got a sheet iron stove made here the same pattern as our own. Camped traveled 13 miles
Completed

2
Journal across the Plains in 1859
Mar 16th the two Hungerfords and myself left Dowagiac this morning on M. C. RR train for Jolliett Ill. to intercept our train that left eight days ago
the day is warm and pleasant. ground thawed out
arrived at Chicago at Noon
took train for Joliet. Arrived at 4.p.m. put up at Central House
found our train at 6.p.m.
Thursday Mar 17th
St Patricks day warm with sunshine my first day with the team
the country is Rocky but soil black and rich
passed through Shonahah village 
I have been elected cook
camped within 6 miles of Morris
traveled 18 miles
Completed

5
by J. A. Wilkinson
Tuesday mar 22nd
weather clear and pleasant. Roads almost impassable ground thawed through to the bottom but not settled the Roads are lined with Pikes Peakers, like ourselves bent on digging gold, but getting along very slow. Camped at noon traveled 4 miles
Wednesday mar 23rd
day warm and clear, layed over to let the Roads dry enjoyed ourselves. Several other teams from Cass. Co. Mich are camped here. we are in the edge of what seems to be a belt of timber. Uncle Dan took some flour over to a Farm House and got some Bread baked. we have music and singing at Night.
Completed

4
journal across the Plains in 1859
Sunday mar 20th
Layed over to let the Roads settle cooked and washed a little my first attempt at making biscuit is a failure, so much so that the oxen wouldn't eat them. we have been travelling along the canal for several days there is much unsettled Prairie land here but all owned by Speculaters. 
Monday mar 21st
Passed through La-Salle and Peru these are two towns close together. the extensive coal mines 400 feet below ground furnish occupation for an immense Foreign population, besides being the terminis of the Illinois Canal, it is the head of navigation on the Illinois River. our oxen are tired pulling through the mud. Camped 3 miles west of town. Traveled 13 miles
Completed

7
by J. A. Wilkinson
Saturday mar 26th,
day pleasant. Mr Brown, and son 12 years old, from Cass County Mich have joined our train. He has only one yoke of oxen and a light wagon but the team is large, young, and smart. Fine farming country, passed through La. Fayette and camped 3 miles beyond. Traveled 13 miles. 
Sunday mar 27th
weather pleasant, layed over, we now have 4 wagons in our train. Old man mominee (the French man) is a good cook and he took pity on me and showed me how to make Biscuits for which I returned thanks. and I think the rest of our mess did also. commenced raining at night and turned cold
Completed

6x
Journal across the plains in 1859
Thursday mar 24th
morning cool and cloudy Resumed our journey Passed through Princeton and Tiskilwa, this is the finest country we have yet seen, and near Princeton is the largest tree nursery in the state country well settled, forded Bureau Creeked. Camped traveled 22 miles
Friday mar 25th
Morning cool. Passed through Providence, the country is low Prairie. Providence looks like a poor place to put much trust in, passed through Oseola and camped one mile beyond traveled 12 miles
Completed

page 9
By J.A. Wilkinson
Wednesday mar 30th
day cool and clear. passed through Walaga, and while crossing the Rail Road 4 miles beyond, about noon. we broke our wagon Axle, this Axle had been broken before in mich and badly welded. A Black Smith shop was close by and we spent 3 hours getting it welded again
We started again and after going 2 miles one of Mr Hungerfords oxen got scared while crossing a culvert, gave a jump and fell dead, we supposed from a Ruptured Blood Vessel.
We took of the Hide, went one mile farther and camped at a very fine Farm House owned by a man by the name of Farnham, within a mile of Galesburg. Traveled 9 miles
Completed

8
Journal across the plains in 1859
Monday mar 28th
Morning cold and rainy. our cattle suffer much from the storm, wild prairie Hay $3 per ton the cheapest we have had yet. had to lay over for the storm. we are in Knox county. the prairie is Rolling and dry and well settled, walnut creek is a Half mile distant. Stopped raining at 4 p.m. and commenced snowing in the Night. Corn 55 cts
Tuesday mar 29th
morning cold with an inch of snow on the ground. Resumed our journey. Crossed Walnut Creek on a Bridge which was nearly under water, passed through victor village. left Altina and Seneca 2 miles to our Right and camped within 2 miles of wataga traveled 15 miles
Completed

11
by J. A. Wilkinson
and said he had been guessing off some to other parties the same way, but our party thought different and I offered to bet there was not 50 pounds. So we brought our steelgards that we carried on purpose and it weighted 45 pounds then the old Farmer would not sell by the weight - but - charged us by the head. This disgusted Uncle Dan who is the soul of Honor and he didn't make himself known, to the man whose son he had accompanied across the plains 9 years before, we passed through Galesburg and some rich country with bad roads and through a fine strip of timber. Hungerfords sold their Hide in Galesburg. Camped within sight of Monmouth traveled 15 miles
Completed

page 10
Journal Across the Plains in 1859
Thursday Mar 31
Weather pleasant. Uncle Dan is a namesake of the farmer where we stayed last night, and stayed at the same place 9 years ago, while on his way to California and one of the sons of the farmer joined the company and went across the plains with them, Uncle Dan would have renewed his aquaintance only for what happened last night.
The old farmer wished to sell us hay by the 100 pounds and guess it off himself and after throwing down a pile off the stack, he got down, measured the distance across and the height by a mark on his pitchfork and pronounced it a 100 pounds --
Completed

13
by J.A. Wilkinson
After packing on about 10 cords of wood we with a lot of other emigrants got our outfits on board at 12 o"clock we started for Burlington 18 miles down stream with a terrible gale blowing in our faces. Our load consisted of 11 wagons, 8 yoke of oxen, 24 horses and mules and 40 men mostly from Michigan. After getting down the river about 5 miles at the rate of about 2 miles an hour it dawned on us that hte old boat was a hulk with poor machinery and couldn't get up steam enough to make steerageway against the wind. in this condition we drifted against an island.
Completed

12
Journal across the plains in 1859
Friday Ap 1st
day pleasant - passed through monmouth and much low prairie and more bad road we had not intended to cross the mississippi at Burlington, but we are informed that we will have to go across to Ozuaka? and ferry down 18 miles to Burlington on account of high water. Camped within 4 miles of Ozawka? traveled 16 miles
Saturday Ap 2nd
Heavy wind and cold, country rolling with some timber on arriving at Oznawka?, we found the Ferry Boat Oznawka?, and would take us on if we would wood her up for the trip.
Completed

15
by J.A. Wilkinson
Sunday Ap 3rd
wind gone down but very cold got our boat started at 6 o'clock in the morning, arrived at Burlington Iowa at 8 o'clock. Fed our teams some corn but could get no hay. went out 6 miles where we found hay and camped within 2 miles of Middletown traveled 6 miles by land and 13 miles by water
Monday Ap 4th
day cold and windy, passed through Middletown, left Centertown on our left and passed through New London, saw the first Plow running today, Prairie very heavy sticky soil. Our teams show the effect of the trip on the Ferry, camped at Job's Tavern. traveled 22 miles
Completed

14
Journal across the plains in 1859
Four o'clock p.m. we are tied up to an island covered with timber and also covered with water with a gale of wind blowing, probably 5 miles to land in any direction All crowed into a little cabin with only standing room with no chance to get any thing to eat and no show? to sleep. Our cattle had to be watched all night by a man on deck with a long pole to keep them from laying down and getting killed. Snowed some in the night, but in spite of all there was some fun and music but a bitter feeling was shown against the crew for getting us on board to keep us from taking another and better boat traveled 9 miles by land and water.
Completed

By J.A. Wilkinson

Wednesday Aug 6th. 

Cool and windy, country considerably unclear, we have been following along the Burlington Rail Road most of the time since learning the Mississippi RIver passed through Fairfield and camped at Batavia?, traveled 18 miles. 
Thursday Aug 7. 
Weather cool. Passed through Ageney and unclear. The last being the present terminess? of the Burlington RR. It is full of business situated on the Des. Moines River. Corn is $1 per bushel and hard to find, hay is $1 per hundred pound and unclear. Ferried the river and camped 2 miles unclear. Traveled 16 miles.
Completed

16
Journal across the plains in 1859
Tuesday Ap 5th
windy with ground frozen a little we ate breakfast this morning with the landlord Mr. Job the Biscuit tasted so musty that the Landlord appologized and said there was no wheat in the state last year that was not sprouted in tho shock? and they couldn't get any good flour this tavern is in the suburbs of Mt Pleasant and within 1/4 of a mile of the large insane asylum which is now building. Sam and I went over th ground it is 2300 feet around the building. passed through a fine body of timber and ferried Skunk River at Rome. camped within 3 miles of Hairfield at a railroad station, traveled 12 miles
Completed

19
by J.A. Wilkinson
Saturday, Apr 9
weather cloudy, passed through Albia about noon and then came into a wild broken country full of Hills and Hollows.
The People seem to be hard up they haven't feed for their own stock, nor corn enough for their own bread, and as for wheat Flour there is no such thing to be had. We find a little Hungarian grass Hay which is good but they thrush it all to get the seed to sow. They sell us the old Prairie Hay covers off their old sheds and let their own stock go hungry to get a little money.
We crossed Cedar Creek this afternoon and camped 7 miles beyond Albia
traveled 14 miles
Completed

Journal Across the Plains in 1859
Friday, April 8th
Snowed last night but pleasant, the country is broken and very poor. Some of us are beginning to see that we were too hasty in getting together our outfits for the trip being so eager to get to the newly discovered gold mines. The [Mominee?] outfit started with a heavy wagon and 2 yoke of oxen, one pair of them old stags and no account. They traded the stags and wagon in Illinois for a light wagon and now have only 1 yoke of oxen. My own yoke of oxen were in [poor?] flesh and being in the lead worked too hard and one of them shows signs of giving out. We passed 1 half mile to the right of Blakesburg and camped within 7 miles of Albia. Traveled 16 miles.
Completed

21
by J.A. Wilkinson
Tuesday Apr 12th
Rained some this morning but cleared off cold.
Passed through Chariton. Our Road is the old Mormon trail the country is settled very thinly although it is open Prairie the best we have seen camped at 4 Pm.
traveled 12 miles
Wednesday Ap 13
We are not making much time because we can't buy corn for the cattle to travel on. Our Route to day has been over open Rolling unsettled Prairie
A terrible cold wind is blowing. we camped in a Quaker Meeting House in the edge of a little settlement
traveled 15 miles
Completed

20
Journal Across the plains in 1859
Sunday Ap 10th
warm and windy
Prairie fires may be seen nearly ever night, the grass grows 4 feet high and falls down in winter. It makes a terrible hot Fire but is worthless for feed, our oxen won't touch it hungry as they are, layed over all day
Monday April 11th
Rained hard last night but is clear this morning, The country is Rolling Prairie and soil loamy and rich.
Corn is $1.50 per bushel we had no more flour left and have to live on corn bread. Passed through Stacyville and La. grange and camped 6 miles beyond
traveled 16 miles
Completed

by J. A. Wilkinson
Saturday April 16
Cold and clear. Resumed our journey. Bought some corn at noon and fed our oxen. Could find no hay in the afternoon, so we camped on Long Creek in the heavy timber within 2 miles of Hopeville. There is lots of dead grass everywhere so we turned our teams out. All made a big fire and proceeded to get supper and let the cattle go where they pleased and so they did for about sundown they couldn't be found. They had gone back 5 miles where they had been fed at noon in a man's barnyard and it took nearly all night to get back. Traveled 10 miles
Completed

Journal Across the plains in 1859
Thursday Apr 14th
Snowed last night and is 4 inches deep this morning. This is the hardest time we have had for ourselves and teams. We have left the main Emigrant Road in order to find more feed. Camped within 12 miles of Hopeville.
traveled 11 miles
Friday Apr 15
Very cold and ground frozen this morning. We have no fire only a sheet iron stove to cook with. Our frozen boots pull on very hard. and the cold wind is searching. we have got some hay near a Farm House and go in every little while and warm our noses. Layed over all day.
Completed

by J. A. Wilkinson
get something he said to caulk the boat, but he didn't come back and I think he was superstitious on account of it being Sunday. So we took some boards up and with buckets bailed it out and pulled our 2 wagons over all right and when we came up to the ferryman's house we found Jake Hungerford - who had distinguished himself before several times about paying bills - quarreling with the ferryman because he wouldn't charge us but made him pay although Jake had gone on and left us to help ourselves.
Went 4 miles beyond the river and camped on the open prairie. Traveled 8 miles
Completed

Journal Across the Plains in 1859
Sunday, April 17
Clear sunshiny spring like day. Started at 10 o'clock. Left Hopeville one mile to our right. Arrived at Grand River ferry in 4 miles after noon. After a while we woke up the ferryman so rods? from the river on the opposite side. Brown and Hungerfirds? put their 4 yoke of oxen in first and pulled them over. Then their 2 wagons the next load. Then came our turn with unclear made 4 yoke, but the ferry was leaking all the time and our oxen sunk it and the oxen went off head first into the river and swam across all right. Then the ferryman seemed to be scared and went to the house to
Completed

by J. A. Wilkinson
Wednesday April 20th
Weather fine and roads good. This is much better country than the Eastern part of Iowa. We can now get corn for 50 cents per bushel. We bought our first potatoes here but they are watery and not fit to eat. They say they can't grow good potatoes here because the land is too rich. Passed through Lexington and and camped 3 miles beyond. Traveled 20 miles.  in Taylor unclear Iowa?
Thursday, April 21st
Cold and snowing this morning, but turned off pleasant the Prairie rolling and well drained with good timber along streams, passed through Hollowayville and camped within a mile of Clarinda on Nodawa? River. Traveled 19 miles.
Completed

Journal Across the Plains in 1859
Monday April 18th
Weather fine, we are getting along slow but we are in no hurry as we are sure of getting to the Missouri River by the time the grass starts. Crossed Sandy Creek and camped on Prairie at Snydertown. Traveled 13 miles. Taylor unclear Iowa?
Tuesday April 19th
We are in a fine country but thinly settled. Crossed 2 branches of Platte River. Traded one of my oxen that was given out for a wild 3 year old steer with a farmer who said he had been to California and worked cows and everything else. Camped on Prairie but didn't unyoke the steer. Traveled 10 miles.  Taylor unclear Iowa?
Completed

by J. A. Wilkinson
Easter Sunday, April 24th
Layed over all day. Very warm and pleasant. Lots of young oak and hickory timber. This is a Mormon settlement. They clain to belong to the Jo Smith tribe and don't believe in having more wives than they have cornbread and bacon to feed. There are 30 wagons camped here. The Mormons charge us what they please for hay and if we object they are insolent. Perhaps they think some of us might have helped to kill Jo Smith. They had preaching in a log church close by and some of our company went. We have had an enjoyable day visiting around among the gold seeking emigrants.
Completed

Journal across the plains in 1859
Friday April 22nd
Country fine and weather warm. There is plenty of prairie chickens and we can shoot them as we go along. It is beginning to be a pleasure to travel but we are in no hurry on account of the backwardness of the grass, passed through Clarinda and camped at noon. Traveled 10 miles.
Saturday, April 23rd
Weather fine - country handsome. Rolling prairie but unsettled. It was 10 miles between houses today. We arrived at Fishers Grove at 2 p.m. and camped on a creek in the Grove. Traveled 14 miles.
Completed

by J. A. Wilkinson
Wednesday Apr 27th
Weather very warm. We can get no hay here and the River is too high to ferry safely over to Nebraska City where we intend to buy our supplies. the grass is starting in the bottoms so our cattle can get enough to live on. layed over all day.
Thursday Apr 28
Warm with River high and lots of driftwood running. There is probably 500 Emigrants camped here waiting to cross water in the River is so muddy we have to settle it before using. Helped to chase a wild turkey gobbler today. Some other boys shot him. Laying over
Completed

Journal Across the plains in 1859
Monday April 25th
Weather warm. Bid good bye to Fishers Grove and the Mormons and traveled on through a fine looking but unsettled country. Crossed 2 branches of unclear River and camped within one half mile of Sidney. Traveled 14 miles.
Tuesday April 26th
Some rain and thunder last night. Drove into Sidney and the county seat of Fremont County. Our company bought their supply of bacon here for the trip at 9 cents a pound. Traveled on across a long stretch of bottom land that is unsettled and camped on Missouri River. Traveled 15 miles.
Completed

by J.A. Wilkinson
Saturday Apr 30th
warm and pleasant, got ferried over to Nebraska City N. J. at 9 AM and commenced to load which took most of the day, nearly every body is half drunk. but merchants and all are good natured. Emigrants help themselves to anything they find in the stores to eat and drink and it is all right. ministers and Deacons are on a drunken frollick this last day in civilization before leaving for the gold mines
Uncle Dan is unclear in lots of things that we had not thought of. Our company consists of the same 4 wagons and 12 men. got loaded and went out 4 miles and camped
traveled 4 miles
Completed

Journal Across the plains in 1859
Friday 29th
Weather pleasant. River falling can't cross teams yet but Dan and I went over to the city and bargained for our supplies as follows
50 lbs sugar at 9 cts
15 lbs coffee at 13 1/2 cts
600 lbs Flour at $ 3.75 per hundred
3 gal jug vinegar $1,50
1/2 bush dried Apples 1.62
3 lbs Cheese at 18 cts per pound
11 lbs rice at 7 cts per pound
1 lbs black pepper 20 cts
1 gal jug Whiskey $1,00
1 bot pepper sauce 25 cts
4 lbs soda 50 cts
2 lbs cream tartar $1.00
4 lbs tea 3.00
2 lbs ginger at 20 cts per pound
25 lbs crackers at 8 cts per pound
1 sack salt 25 cts
1 bottle Brandy 50 cts
Completed

by J. A. Wilkinson
Monday May 2nd
Blowed terribly last night and rained and thundered heard wolves howling for the first time since I was 8 years old in Michigan. We are on what is called the divide between weeping water on our Right and {Nemachah?] River on our left. The country is rolling prairie with plenty of water in the sloughs and ravines. [Unclear] weaping water at 4 P.M. and broke our wagon axle a few rods beyond the same one that we broke in Illinois. We used bad judgment in starting with this old Iron Axle wagon, we pulled away from the road a piece and camped. Lucky we didn't get any further.
Traveled 15 miles
Completed

Journal Across the Plains in 1859
Sunday May 1st
Robinson and Bilderback went back to the city this morning to get somethings they had forgotten this is as fine Prairie Country as any we have seen, the grass is short but growing fast.
Completed

by J.A. Wilkinson                                                                                                                                                                                                                                             37
Thursday May 5th started for camp before daylight.  Saw a good many teams on the Road today and Arrived in camp at 3 p.m.  found that as soon as we had left camp for the city, the Hungerfords and  Brown had pulled out saying they would travel along slow so we could catch up, thus leaving only Mominee Bilderback and Robinson with Uncle Dan.
We got loaded up ready for a start in the morning/  The feed has grown fast and is good.  We are about 30 miles west of Nebraska City.  Weeping Water is a small stream with steep banks
Completed

Journal Across the plains in 1859
Tuesday May 3rd
Rained hard last night. We had unloaded our wagon and took the Axle off ready for a start back to the city. Dan and I started early with one yoke of oxen and the forward running gears and the other Axle and our blankets lashed on. All of the company agreed to stay with Uncle Dan until we got back.
Camped within 4 miles of town
Wednesday May 4th
Had to tie our oxen to the wagon wheel at night but were up before daylight letting the oxen feed. Went into the city got the Axle minded and went out about 10 miles and camped.
Completed

by J.A. Wilkinson                                                                                                                                                                                                                                          39
Saturday May 7th
Rained some last night Passed a government train owned by Majors and Russell it consist of 26 wagons with 6 yoke of oxen to the wagon They have a wagon master and his word is law and gospel.  the wagons are all wooden Axle with Lock chains instead of brakes  They are made in Mishaw aka Indiana, and are all loaded with 4 unclear pounds besides the mens provisions and go to the forts on the plains when they camp they drive their wagons in a circle that forms a corrall for yoking the oxen in.  We met 2 teams going back The men didn't seem to want to talk with us.  Camped near a place where a man was murdered  Traveled 20 miles
Completed

38
Journal Across the plains in 1859
Friday May 6th
Started Early.  we think to overtake Hungerfords and Brown next Sunday if they lay over and don't go too fast.
Arrived at Salt Creek at 3 p.m. and were surprised to find a Farm fenced in and corn to sell.  These settlers have put up a Bridge of Cottonwood poles and charge toll when the creek is too high to ford.  Which is the case today.  Water in the creek is salt.  We picked up some wood went 4 miles further and camped this prairie country is full of sloughs, gorges, ravines or draws as some call things pools of water form in them.  some of them deep and good to drink from.  traveled 18 miles
Completed

41

by J.A. Wilkinson
Monday May 9th
meeting lots of teams.  the men seem to be excited and mad  They say they have met teams that have been through to the mines and they are a Humbug.  At noon we stopped as usual to feed and lunch.  on going a half mile we found Brown and the Hungerfords nooning with their wagons turned towards Pikes Peak to deceive us.  Jake who was a sort of a boss was to cold hearted and cowardly to want to say good bye to us, but he didn't fool us at at all.  Jake gave us some Fatherly advice and we parted.  Mominee and the Boys kept on with us met 100 teams today going back
traveled 25 miles
Completed

40
Journal Across the plains in 1859
Sunday May 8th
Went to the Grave of the murdered man and talked with the men who found the body and fished it out of one of the deep water holes in one of the gulches nearby. by some papers found on the body his name is supposed to be Carpenter coming back from Pikes Peak with one Curtis.  was about 25 years old dark Hair, Sandy Beard.  He was short probably by Curtis - 3 times in the back.  Saw 5 Buffalo and 2 Antelope off at a distance.  we met some more returning teams today.  They said Pikes Peak Gold mines were a humbug and we were fools to go any further 
traveled 25 miles
Completed

43
by J.A. Wilkinson
Wednesday May 11
Since leaving Elm Creek our Route has been up the Platte River.  yesterday noon we parted Clear Creek another turning table where hundreds of Emigrants are camped arguing and quarrelling about which way to go.  Some are cutting their wagons into making carts one half going back and the other going on.  we are meeting 200 teams a day and some who claim to have been through have some specimens of brass gold dust that mines were salted with.  Hail storm last night.  our oxen travel like horses and the Road is smooth and fine Camped on Platte Bottoms
traveled 25 miles
Completed

42 
Journal Across the plains in 1859
Tuesday May 10th
the Mominee outfit have only 1 yoke of oxen and the Boys Bilderback and Robinson are discouraged about Pikes Peak and don't want to go to California.  they sat up nearly all last night and talked over the matter This morning they decided to go back, and Bilderback started early on foot to overtake Hungerfords and left Robinson and Mominee to come along with the wagon Mominee wants to go to California but they cant make 2 teams of 1 yoke of oxen.  Elm Creek is a turning table a mile from here and we left poor Mominee trying to get a chance to go through.  traveled 25 miles.
Completed

45
by J.A. Wilkinson
Friday May 13th
Road continues up Platte valley
Raining some today.
Saw several Hundred Buffaloes
off at a distance today noon.
wood is hard to get
and we have to burn
Buffalo chips and young
green willows most of the time.
We have thrown away
the sheet Iron stove and
many other things that
we bought to mine with.
We could buy provisions
of the return Emigrants
for one half what they
cost in the city but we 
have more than we want
to go to California with.
Grass is short but very
nutritious and our unclear do well
camped opposite Grand Island
traveled 25 miles
Completed

44
Journal Across the plains in 1859
Thursday May 12th
Meeting teams all the time 
Men who started in February 
with Hand Carts and Pack 
mules and ponies are now 
on their way back on foot 
without Blankets or food.  begging of every wagon 
they meet for something to eat.  
Met today noon one of old Gideon Allen's sons 
from Cass County Michigan he had given his mule 
to a man to take him back
to Nebraska City, but he
was in good spirits and had
buckskin paches on the Seat
of his.  we are traveling
with 4 other teams going to
California, but have not 
formed a company with a Captain yet
traveled 25 miles
Completed

47
by J.A. Wilkinson
Sunday May 15th
Still opposite Grand Island
and laying over for the Rain.
No tidings yet of the lost
Horses which are probably
stolen and run off by the Indians.
We organized into a 
company today for self
protection and Government
with 9 wagons as follows
Jesse Griffith & co 1 wagon
Mr Overman & co 2 "
Evan Crane & co 1 "
Mr Cooper & co 1 "
Mr McGee & co 1 "
Mr Daugherty & co 1 "
Mr Olson & co Norwegians 1 "
Myself, Uncle Dan & Son Dan 1 wagon
Jesse Griffith of Ottumwa
Iowa, was Elected Captain
our Captain is a dignified big nosed
good natured old Bachelor.
Completed

46
Journal Across the plains in 1859
Saturday May 14th
Rainy and cold and layed
over all day more than 20
teams are encamped here.
about half on the back track 
there is a kind of Minstrell
Show Company with a Big Tent.
they make lots of fun and
music every night
Some of the men have lost
their Horses and have
men out hunting for them
but they returned about
bed time tonight without
finding their tracks
wood is scare and one
man swam the Platte and
tired a long Rope to a log which
we pulled over.  we dug a
trench in the ground to 
keep the wind from blowing
our fire away.
Completed

by J. A Wilkinson
Tuesday, May 17th
Our road continues up the Platte bottoms on the South Side. Some Alkali water stands after the rain which we have to [guard?] the cattle against drinking. Arrived this forenoon to where the St. Jo Road comes into ours. Two men are building a Sod House here for a trading post. Their stock of goods consists of a barrel of whiskey with a little tin cup. the customer helps himself with what he can drink for 25 cts. We passed Fort Kearny at 3 p.m. They have barracks here with  houses for officers. The soldiers put up lots of hay and have a vegetable garden. We are not allowed to stop near the Fort so we camped 4 miles out. Traveled 25 miles
Completed

48 
Journal Across the Plains in 1859
Monday May 16th
Resumed our journey this morning. Our Captain has taken our names and we have to stand guard at night one half a night at a time when our turns come except Uncle Dan who is exempt on account of his Age. We turn out at 4 or 5 P.M. so our teams get enough to eat before dark when they are bunched up until they lie down, and if one gets up in the night he must be watched until he lies down again. And at 3 1/2 A.M. they must have extra guard as they get up to Eat, Ready for an Early Start
traveled 25 miles
Completed

by J. A. Wilkinson
Thursday, May 19th
Grass better and less Alkali Platte River is full of islands and well timbered with cottonwood. There are so many channels that you can't tell which is the main one, and the water is too muddy to be fit to drink without being settled.
Crossed Plum Creek at noon. One of our men, Johnson Wolverton got a letter at the Fort from a Friend who had preceeded him to Pikes Peak, and was overloaded, telling him to dig up from a newly made Grave such a distance from the Fort a box of whiskey in bottles. It seems the man was owing Wolverton and took this way to pay.
Traveled 22 miles
Completed

Journal Across the plains in 1859
Wednesday, May 18th
Short grass and willows forward. Met an empty Government train returning from Salt Lake. Several women are in the train - probably runaways - they couple 3 or 4 wagons together to save drivers and drive the rest of the stock loose. We are never out of sight of the River on our right or the Bluffs on our left. Saw Buffalo and Antelope off at a distance. I have never seen a coyote yet although they are howling by the hundreds every night all around us. There is a large jack rabbit here with shorted faces. They turn their heads to one side when they run.
Traveled 25 miles
Completed

53
by J.A. Wilkinson
Saturday May 21st
Weather clear and pleasant. one Hundred teams may be counted at once on both sides of the River this morning The only old Californian in our train besides Uncle Dan Farnham is a lame man by the name of Snyder. Buffalo grass as they call it here is very Rich it grows in the Bottoms? and is a dark green color.
Camped at Cottonwood Springs, traveled 20 miles
Sunday May 22nd
Layed over all day, washing and cooking. Plenty of Red Cedar in the Ravines, this is a trading post and stage station with several Lay cabins
Completed

Journal Across the plains in 1859
Friday May 20th
Thunderstorm last night. Wolverton's whiskey sells very readily. We are still meeting returning Pikes Peakers some of them hard up they have taxed our bread basket rather heavy but we have never refused them yet although we see some of our company do it by saying they had no bread baked when they have crackers and hard tack a plenty. For the last 10 days our road has been up the bottom except about 10 miles.
Saw a new grave marked "John Snyder, Shot by James Garner May 14th" - cold night, Traveled 22 miles
Completed

55
by J.A. Wilkinson
Tuesday May 24th
Passed Fremonts Springs at 9 A.M. and stopped at Ofallons Bluffs at noon. here is a stage station, trading post, post office and an Indian village inhabited by the Sioux's they are tall and sullen looking. We have met a lot of them on the Road going to fight the Pawnees, but have not seen a village before. they have a Burying place about 20 mile distant where they put their dead up on a platform to rot, and I looked through a Spy Glass at them I thought I could smell them.
The Platte forks near here we sent Letters back from Offallons Bluffs. Thunder storm at night camped on the River. traveled 25 miles
Completed

54
Journal across the plains in 1859
Monday May 23rd
warm and pleasant.
left Cottonwood Springs and traveled up the valley. Since we get plenty of wood I bake all the Bread in a bake kettle at night. I divide the batch in 3 parts. one loaf for supper one loaf bakes while we eat supper and the other one in the evening for our lunch at noon. So we dont have much cooking in the morning and none at noon. Uncle Dan is the first man up in the camp and helps to look after the cattle and gathers wood and helps to cook. Turns very windy at night camped on a creek running through the valley. traveled 25 miles
Completed

57
by J.A. Wilkinson
Thursday May 26th
Rather cold. Feed is good
Resumed our journey up the South Side of the South Platte. This is on the regular Pikes Peak Road, but tomorrow we cross the Platte and will see no more returning starved Pikes Peakers and I am glad of it. Uncle Dan thinks if he can get to Hangtown California he can make a raise in the mines yet, and as for Dan and myself we haven't anything to loose by going and nothing to make by going back to Michigan.
Met more Sioux Indians going to fight the Pawnees in Eastern Nebraska Territory.
Camped within 12 miles of the crossing
traveled 25 miles
Completed

56
Journal Across the plains in 1859
Wednesday May 24th
Rainy and cold.
Layed over all day.
Our Flour that we bought at the frontier although made of Spring wheat is good and makes as good short cake as I ever ate any where.
Mr Overman who is an old Kentuckian borrows our Bake Kettle every time we lay over and Bakes himself a corn Pone.
We have lots of Beans but don't have time to cook them only when we lay over, and then we eat so hearty of them that we are Sick.
They would be good in mining camp, but not good to travel with. We have 2 fiddlers in our company and sometimes have a regular stag dance.
Completed

59
by J.A. Wilkinson
holes or some times the leaders are in swimming water but the rope takes them alond??.
The traders have a flat boat that they operate with Indians and do a good business hauling goods over. Some Horses won't swim but lie down and have to be choked and pulled over with ropes, and mules are worse than horses.
We have some fun in spite of cold water and danger of getting in over our heads. The channel is changing all the time and the Indians make something acting as guides. We got over all right changed our clothes took a turn at the jug just for spiritual consolation. went 3 miles towards North Platte and camped
traveled 15 miles
Completed

58
Journal Across the plains in 1859
Friday May 27th
Find some Alkali water standing in pools that we have to guard against. Arrived at the ford of South Platte at noon. 
There is an Indian Village and trading Post here.
We begin preparations for crossing by making a temporary platform across the top of our wagon boxes to get our provisions above water. The River is a shifting bed of quick sand from 4 to 5 feet deep and over a quarter of a mile wide. we put 6 yoke of cattle on a wagon and with 2 men with a long rope ahead of the leaders and men on each side of the wagon with poles to keep it from upsetting when going into
Completed

61
by J.A. Wilkinson
Sunday May 29th
Valley narrow Bluffs high and rocky. Some Alkali and plenty of dry Red cedar for wood.
Weather warm in midle of the day. A black Hail Storm came up after we camped tonight these storms are frequent and dangerous on account of stampeding our cattle. Roads sandy
traveled 20 miles
Monday May 30th
Same Alkali. Roads sandy and heavy. wolves and Coyotes make nights hideous
Saw a grey wolf larger than a newfoundland dog.
Prairie dogs are barking at us all along the Roads they live in holes like Badgers in villages. Camped on Ash Creek traveled 25 miles
Completed

60
Journal Across the plains in 1859
Saturday May 28th
Country Rolling Prairie and not very good sail. Arrived at Ash Hollow at noon and stopped at a fine spring a mile from the North Platte. this is the place where General Harney killed so many Indians with the soldiers. we met a lot of Siouxs today with their families moving. the wigwam poles some 20 feet long are lashed to the sides of the Ponies and Baskets are lashed to the poles behind the Pony where the Pappooses are carried
This Hollow is the most dangerous place to be attacked by Indians that we have seen on the whole Route.Passed a trading Post this afternoon went 5 miles beyond and camped
traveled 20 miles
Completed

63
by J.A. Wilkinson
Wednesday June 1st
we are nearly opposite Chimney Rock on our left this morning, and Several of our company with myself Struck out to visit the Rock 5 miles distant in the valley. no one but a Geologist could tell how it is formed
It has a Base of Several hundred feet, we climbed up a couple of hundred feet cut our names in a strata of chalk Rock, and above that are groups of chimney like columns of crumbly Rock that is probably 200 feet high all the time crumbling and falling in little particles by the action of the wind and rain.
It is truly a great natural curiosity camped under Scotts Bluffs at a Spring
traveled 30 miles
Completed

62
Journal of Across the plains in 1859
Tuesday May 31st
Some Scrubby Pine in the Bluffs on our left Plat River is on our Right.
large Pools of Alkali water.
Stopped on a creek opposite Court House Rock, with Chimney Rock visable in the distance. Some of the boys visited Court House Rock which is a natural curiosity It was my turn to drive and couldn't go.
distance is very deceiving here. what you think is one mile distant is five on account of the clearness of the atmosphere. the boys came in late from visiting the Rock tired out and much surprised as to distance
traveled 30 miles
Completed

65
by J.A. Wilkinson
Friday June 3rd
Mrs Cooper is the only woman in the Train. Mr Overman has the only 2 mules in the train and drives them himself or rather he goes behind and sleeps and the mules drive themselves, he also has 2 cows that his Boy 14 years old drives along behind.
Still up the Platte Valley
traveled 20 miles
Saturday June 4
Laramie Peak looks plain in the distance.
Lots of Red cedar and Scrubby Pine in the Bluffs and mountains, Passed Indian Village, trading Post and Black smith Shop and camped one mile beyond for the day. traveled 5 miles
Completed

64
Journal Across the plains in 1859
Thursday June 2nd
Close under the East Side of Scotts Bluffs or rather a Spur of a mountain with a natural Pass through it for a wagon Road only a few rods wide with nearly perpendicular walls.
These bluffs are named after a man who it is said was pursued by the Indians and hid in a cave and starved to death rather than be taken, Beyond the Bluffs we came to an Indian village on the Platte and a trading Post kept by an old Frenchman with a Squaw for a wife.
we don't meet any more Pike Peakers as their Road led up South Platte. Crossed Horse Creek and camped 1 mile beyond.
traveled 20 miles.
Completed

67
by J.A. Wilkinson
Woolen Soldier Coats buttoned up under their chins, and a guard standing over them with a loaded musket. They have been drunk on Emigrant whiskey.
There is a Bushel of letters in the Fort and everybody looks them over and take what belongs to them, and mail Letters for home. 
They put 6 little Spanish mules on a Stage and a man called a whiperene Rides an American mule along side licking them up hill and down, while the driver steers them.
we traveled up the Platte and camped at what seemed to be the end of the valley Red Cedar and Pine getting thicker.
traveled 20 miles
Completed

66
Journal Across the plains in 1859
Sunday June 5th
Our Captain has a guide Book but it don't seem to be always reliable.
We are within 9 miles of Fort Larimie on Larimie River where it comes into the Platte, very warm and threatens to rain. Layed over all day, and Overman had his Regular corn Pone.
Monday June 6th
Started early. Crossed the Larimie at the Fort on a Bridge toll $2.50
A Road comes in here from Pikes Peak there are some soldiers here and 2 of them are chopping wood at a pile of dry cottonwood poles in the Hot Sun, with their
Completed

69
by J.A. Wilkinson
Thursday June 9th
After going one mile came to a creek with a spring to the right. Some cattle ran by us last night on a stampede from a train ahead of us. Our cattle were too tired to run and that saved us. Stopped at noon without water and camped at night in a ravine and dug for water. Our guide Book is all the time getting us into trouble. we saw 2 men saving Boards out of Pine logs with a whip or Pit saw.
The logs are up on a scaffold and the lower man stands in a trench. the logs were about a foot in diameter.
traveled 20 miles
Completed

68
Journal Across the plains in 1859
Tuesday June 7th
Road leads into the Black Hills. Called so from the dark green color of the Cedar and Pine.
Stopped at noon on a creek and camped at night at twin Springs.
traveled 20 miles
Wednesday June 8th
Crossed Horse Shoe Creek this forenoon, there is a Trading Post and Station on the creek. Roads are hilly an some of our cattle are getting foot sore from going into the water and travelling on gravelly Roads. We traveled until 9 o'clock at night. Camped and dug for water.
traveled 30 miles.
Completed

71
by J.A. Wilkinson
Saturday June 11th
Traveled 5 miles up the River and camped for the day to cook, wash and mend up.
we are in a fine quaking Ash Grove as most of our company call the timber, but in michigan we call it popple. It grows very tall and large sometimes 2 metres? in diameter.
About as many people are travelling on the North as on our side of the Platte, and to day we saw a drove of 700 cattle across the River belonging to Major Jake Clark of California.
We are with in 12 miles of the Bridge where we intend to cross 
Uncle Dan's Big Ox Bally is so sore footed that he has to be driven behind with the loose cattle.
traveled 5 miles.
Completed

70
Journal Across the plains in 1859
Friday June 10th
Came to Gallee Creek while 2 miles on the Road and Box elder Creek a few miles further on. and stopped at noon, on Platte River. Arrived at Deer Creek 4 P.M. There is a trading post and Indian Village here, and opposite a short distance is a ferry across the Platte.
Our Cream Tartar has given out and I bought some Tartaric Acid here at $1.- per pound.
Some of this country is fine to look at and would do to live in only for the Indians.
we are not going to cross at the ferry. went 2 miles out and camped on the River.
traveled 23 miles
Completed

73
by J.A. Wilkinson
or deer skin or furs as the case may be, and they have to take it or no trade.
Crossed over, went 5 miles up the River and camped.
while in camp this evening came across an old sunday school chum. a young man by the name of Irving Kimball son of Timothy Kimball of Elkhart Indiana. His Father is now in California and he is taking across some Horses. He has a sort of a Boy crowd and they have taken poor care of their Horses and they look bad. they go by Salt Lake so they can get grain for their teams. and we go to Sublets Cutoff North of Salt Lake and will not see then after tomorrow.
traveled 17 miles.
Completed

72
Journal Across the plains in 1859
Sunday June 12th
Started early and arrived at the Bridge at 2 P.M.
Indian village and trading Post here, the Bridge belongs to a French man, it is built of cottonwood timber with hewed poles for a floor, and as the River is deep and swift it must have cost some money the toll is $3.00 per wagon.
The French man has a large store filled with several thousand Dollars worth of goods, only one Indian is allowed to go in to trade at a time.
there are several Clerks and Servants. they will hold up a little tin cup full of sugar, flour, coffe or crackers, and motion with the fingers how many they will give for an Antelope
Completed

75
by J.A. Wilkinson
Wednesday June 15th
Arrived at toll Bridge and Black Smith Shop on Sweet Water at noon. they have a young Cinnamon Bear taming at the shop. Continued on to the upper crossing and forded the River to save toll. went 5 miles further passing around Independence Rock which is a solid mountain of granite. Camped early at a mail station at the western entrance of the Devils gate. Swam our cattle across the River to get good feed. Explored the Devils gate which is a mountain split in two where the River rushes through with deafening Roar, the chasm having almost perpendicular walls 400 feet high.
traveled 15 miles.
Completed

74
Journal Across the plains in 1859
Monday June 13th
This forenoon we found a good thimble skein wagon that had been abandoned. Mr McGee left his own wooden axle wagon and hitched onto it and made a good trade. Left the River in 12 miles, and camped at night at Willow Springs
traveled 30 miles
Tuesday June 14th
By an overdrive yesterday we overtook the Kimball train at the springs, but they have left us this morning probably for good.
Roads are heavy and our teams need rest. Camped on Horse Creek for the day
traveled 10 miles
Completed

77
by J.A.Wilkinson
Saturday June 18th
Very sandy. Took the cut off Road and arrived at the River again in 12 miles.
Uncle Dan has been telling us about digging ice up out of the ground somewhere on the plains but can't tell where it is located.
This afternoon Mr Snyder an old Californian who is lame and walks with a cane, went out into the Alkali marsh and found the ice by running his cane down in the mud. We dug some which was 10 inches thick and although it was in the mud it was good and free from Alkali. Nobody can explain the phenomena. Camped at Hot Springs on the left of the Road. traveled 25 miles
Completed

76
Journal Across the plains in 1859
Thursday June 16th
Road led up the Sweetwater through a Canyon.
the more proper name of this small stream is wind River and it heads in wind River Mountains at Fremonts Peak.
Which we can see to the North of the South Pass of the Rocky Range.
Camped at 4 P.M.
traveled 20 miles
Friday June 17th
we are in a high altitude but we have come to it so gradual that we don't realize it. the days are warm but nights are cool
Feed is very poor and roads heavy camped at noon within one mile of stage station
traveled 12 miles
Completed

79
by J.A. Wilkinson
Monday June 20th
Layed over all day,
washed cooked and jerked our Antelope and Elk and dried it and Smoked it what we could. About 40 pounds fell to our lot and is a good change from the Regular fat Bacon.
Tuesday June 21st
Resumed our journey and made 12 miles by noon. Grazed on the River and camped on the Sweet water at night by a stage station by the side of a snow bank that had not melted from last winter. this is the last water that runs into the Atlantic Ocean on our Road.
traveled 20 miles
Completed

78
Journal Across the plains in 1859
Sunday June 19th
Started at 4 o'clock in the morning passed Cold Spring and another watering place and camped at noon at a large spring for the day.
Several of the Boys went hunting and killed an Antelope.
About sundown An Elk came trotting by the camp with his tongue out probably was chased by wolves.
Every Rifle was brought to bear on him besides Colts Revolvers, but he kept on and 2 men jumped onto Overman's mules with Revolvers and overtook the Elk - he being wounded and killed him.
the Elk dressed 412 pounds and the camp was named Elk Springs
traveled 12 miles
Completed

81
by J.A. Wilkinson
Thursday June 23rd
Started at 2 P.M. and arrived at Big Sandy Creek at 8 miles distant and camped
traveled 8 miles
Friday June 24th
Crossed Big Sandy Creek in the morning and stopped on a creek at noon and camped on Big Sandy. 
We saw today where the mormons had burned a government train a year ago, giving the teamsters what provisions they could pack on their backs and drove the oxen to Salt Lake
we are within 5 miles of Green River
traveled 15 miles
Completed

80
Journal Across the plains in 1859
Wednesday June 22nd
we are in the South Pass, on the back-bone of the Continent although it is a level plain several miles wide.
We arrive at Pacific Springs - the first water that runs into the Pacific Ocean in 12 miles. Grazed our cattle ready for a drive across a 25 mile desert.
Started across the desert at 5 P.M. and made the trip without a stop and arrived at little sandy at day light June 23rd 
Roads are very sandy but nights quite cool and comfortable to travel distance traveled since yesterday morning 
37 miles
Completed

83
by J.A. Wilkinson
as they turned around and came back, we have to put them in single file and if the leader keeps his head to the opposite shore they follow. The second attempt was a success even Uncle Dans old Bally made it all right. 
A wild steer that Daugherty traded for yesterday got away with a yoke and a heavy cable chain attached to him. it was thought he would drowned but came out a half mile below. We joined in with another train for more safety against the Indians on this cut off - making 19 wagons, 120 head of stock, 75 men and a few women and children.
went 3 miles up the valley and camped in the river for the day
traveled 8 miles
Completed

82
Journal Across the plains in 1859
Saturday June 25th
Arrived at Green River early in the forenoon. We found several other teams Ready to cross. the Salt Lake Route keeps down the East Side and we cross and take up the west side on the sublet cut off.
Green River is very swift, full of swirls and hard to swim. It empties into the Colorado, there is a trading Post and ferry here.
We sold some flour and Beans at the store, ferried all our wagons and those who had Horses and mules did the same, then we drove our cattle over a Hundred head - up the River a half a mile swam them across. the first attempt was a failure
Completed

85
by J.A. Wilkinson
Monday June 27th
Mosquitoes are terrible
we picked some wild gooseberries and stewed them and eat them without sugar, partly because sugar is scarce, and partly because they are good for our Alkalied stomachs. passed a spring this afternoon and camped on a spring at the foot of a mountain in what we have named mosquito Valley.
traveled 25 miles
Tuesday June 28
There is no comfort day or night for musketoes. cooking or eating is out of the question and the stock and suffering terribly. Forded Hams fork of Green River at noon and camped on the mountain at a Spring. traveled 20 miles
Completed

84
Journal Across the plains in 1859
Sunday June 26th
Left the River after going 6 miles, and 8 miles further on we came to Slate Creek, and stopped for noon. made 11 miles in the afternoon and camped on Slate Creek. the Roads are heavy and Rocky. Sage brush grows every where in this desert country. Some of it grows 4 feet high branching out close to the ground with a body 4 to 6 inches in diameter. It has leaves some like sage. has an aromatic smell like wormwood. Makes a hot fire, and the Blacksmith makes coal of it when wood is scarse.
The smell of it is said to cure consumptives who cross the plains
traveled 25 miles
Completed

87
by J.A. Wilkinson
Thursday June 30th
At one o'clock this morning the cool breeze off the mountain quieted the musketoes and we began by sorting the wagons into wide and narrow track lots, then placed the stringers and let the inside of the hubs run on the timbers and with men to lift them over the Bents and ropes to the end of the wagon tongues they were soon jerked over. The stock were driven up about a half a mile to a favorable place and swum over. Arrived at Thomas' Fork of Bear River at noon
Forded the stream and went over a mountain and camped on the main Bear River
traveled 18 miles
Completed

86
Journal Across the plains in 1859
Wednesday June 29th
We are on the top of Bear River Mountains and saw snow a quarter of a mile from the Road yesterday
went down off the mountain this forenoon on a very steep and dangerous grade, into Bear River Valley followed down the Valley and arrived at Smiths fork of Bear River at 4 P.M. this stream is a swift mountain torrent with a Bridge but the floor timbers are gone, only the Bents and Stringers left.
Our stock are so crazy with the musketoes that we will have to wait until midnight to cross our wagons as that is the only time we can work
traveled 15 miles
Completed

89
by J.A. Wilkinson
Saturday July 2nd
Our Road leads down the valley. the River runs North west some fine farms could be made here as the land is rich with meadows of Red top and other grasses.
the scenery is fine and strawberries and gooseberries are plentiful and occasionally a wild Plum tree.
To day noon we got out of the musketoes which was a great relief this afternoon we are going around the Horse Shoe bend of the River and it takes off towards Salt Lake in a Southwesterly direction.
Arrived at Soda Springs where there is a lot of Indians, and camped
traveled 18 miles
Completed

88
Journal Across the plains in 1859
Friday July 1st
Every man declares that he never saw musketoes before in his life. They make a cloud that is easily seen when looking towards the sun they are the worst on the lead teams so that the team in lead drops back every half hour to the rear. There is fine feed on this cut off with no Alkali but our stock are terribly Poisoned, Starved and used up. Every man is worn out for sleep. No traders nor Indians are visible for they couldn't live. Saw some Indian tracks today and a large Bear track with them.
our road led down the valley all day, and we camped on a creek 
traveled 15 miles
Completed

91
by J.A. Wilkinson
Monday July 4th
The Sykeses are old Californian and crossed the plains in 1850 in the company with Uncle Dan. Hiram Spencers team have some of them given out and he has gone in with Larin Sykes and left his own wagon on the Road. Henry Spencer his Brother who was driving his way through wanted to come in with us, and we finally consented. the Sykeses or Rushers and by the looks they have been driving to hard.
We left Bear River in 2 miles this morning and went 12 miles further and camped on a creek for the day in a Popple Grove to celebrate the fourth
traveled 14 miles
Completed

90
Journal across the plains in 1859
Sunday July 3rd
Layed over all day.
there is the finest of Soda Water at these springs. we are on the river Bank and some of the Boys went in bathing, the water is cold and clear.
I beleave there is 500 Indians camped here and they are very insolent knowing that they outnumber us. They have a monstrous big tame Bear. The Sykes train came up this afternoon. Lorin Sykes and Family, Zene Sykes and Family and Hiram Spencer and Family and Henry Spencer and Brother all old Neighbors in Vanburen County Michigan. 
They had been by the way of Pikes Peak having started very early and had now overtaken us.
Completed

93
by J.A. Wilkinson
we overtook our train at noon on a creek, and we remained in camp until some of the rest of the company went back and got some things they needed. The only explanation that can be given is that they were camped to recruit their teams and that their cattle had been run off by Indians, and the men were obliged to take what they could carry on their backs. They had burned their yokes after losing their cattle and eating their supper at night were frightened away as their meal was left half eaten. Went 6 miles in the afternoon and camped on a Creek. traveled 16 miles
Completed

92
Journal Across the plains in 1859
Tuesday July 5th
Arrived at fall River at noon. Plenty of feed and good water. traveled 7 miles in the Afternoon and camped on Swamp Creek
traveled 15 miles
Wednesday July 6th
This forenoon while Bill Brink and I were out hunting 3 miles from the Road we found a deserted camp with one wagon, 2 large tents, some provisions, lots of camp kettles, canteens, knives, forks, spoons, and some bedding. The ox yokes had been burned and the camp deserted about 2 weeks. I brought away a tent and a half Bushel of corn meal, Brink took a cotton mattrass and a canteen.
Completed

95
by J.A. Wilkinson
Saturday July 9th
Went down 20 mile canyon and stopped at Willow Creek at noon and camped on a creek at 3 o'clock within 9 miles of Raft River
traveled 15 miles
Sunday July 10th
Stopped at noon on Raft River. Went 6 miles in the afternoon and camped early on account of Hail Storm.
traveled 15 miles
Monday July 11th
Stopped on a creek at noon and camped at a spring in the mountain. Lost one of my oxen by Poison Parsnip. We have only 2 yoke left able to drive
traveled 20 miles
Completed

94
Journal Across the plains in 1859
Thursday July 75th
Crossed Crab Creek at 9 o'clock 6 miles out and by mistake took no water to drink as it was 23 miles further without water. went down a canyon 4 miles long and very steep had to put one yoke of oxen on the tongue and two yoke behind to hold back
It was very warm and we suffered for water some. Reached a creek at 10 o'clock at night and camped with the Sykes train. traveled 29 miles
Friday July 8
Horses and cattle are dying on account of Poison Parsnip and musketoe bites. Camped at first spring
traveled 6 miles
Completed

97
by J.A. Wilkinson
arrested for being with the Indians and painted up and Bossing? the shooting.
This young fellow and an old man have a Brush Camp on the creek.
The old Frenchman is better this morning and will be able to Ride in a spring wagon to day. the Emigrants were going to Hang the young man but the old Frenchman Refused to swear positively to his Identity this morning, but he is undoubtedly guilty.
A collection was taken up and money enough given to hire himself hauled through in a Spring wagon.
Camped on Goose Creek
traveled 15 miles
Completed

96
Journal Across the plains in 1859
Tuesday July 12th
We passed City of Rocks this forenoon within 5 miles of the junction of the Salt Lake Road.
Stopped at noon on a creek and spring in a canyon, and camped on Goose Creek at table mountain.
traveled 20 miles
Wednesday July 13th
Travelling up Goose Creek. A French man who was packing with a Pony alone was shot in the back yesterday with an Arrow and his Pony run off. His name is Louis Philippe. Some Emigrants have him taking care of, and a young mormon
Completed

99
by J.A. Wilkinson
Friday July 15th
Good feed is hard to find, camped in thousand spring valley, have to watch our oxen to keep them from getting into bottomless spring holes of Hot and cold water
traveled 12 miles
Saturday July 16th
Rough country and very little soil good for anything. Camped at night in the mouth of a canyon at the End of thousand spring valley.
We find Red and yellow currants, also Service berries and a little Red berry called Barberries? that are very sour
traveled 15 miles
Completed

98
Journal Across the plains in 1859
Thursday July 14th
Arrived at Rock Springs at noon. Hiram Spencer and Family have become dissatisfied with their treatment in the Sykes train and we have taken them in with us. They have one good yoke of oxen that are able to work and a stag that is sore footed, and a nice little cow that is giving milk and broken to work.
This gives us 3 yoke to work and 2 sore footed ones bringing up the Rear with the cow.
Our mess consists of 5 men one woman and a child.
We have got back to our original 9 wagon train as before we started on the Sublet cut off.
Made 6 miles in the afternoon and camped
traveled 18 miles
Completed

101
by J.A. Wilkinson
Wednesday July 20th
We are in sight of the Humbolt Valley on our Right. The Indians shot one of the Norwegians oxen last night with an Arrow through the Ear. they are a sneaking tribe these "Piutes"? and have no guns and live mostly on Sage Rats
Camped at an old deserted trading Post
traveled 20 miles
Thursday July 21st
The Norwegians started with 2 yoke of cattle and have got down to one yoke. they have coupled up their wagons to save weight and thrown away the Box. Camped on a creek. traveled 20 miles
Completed

100
Journal Across the plains in 1859
Sunday July 17th
10 miles to water where we stopped at noon.
Made 10 miles afternoon and camped at Spring Wells.
traveled 20 miles
Monday July 18th
Arrived at trout creek and camped for the day bought some speckled Brook Trout of the Indians
the Roads having forked we are on the Bluff Road leaving the Humbolt River Road to the right
traveled 10 miles
Tuesday July 19th
Plenty of water but no feed camped at a spring to the left of the Road. traveled 20 miles
Completed

103
by J.A. Wilkinson
Monday July 25th
Passed down the steepest mountain Road into the valley this afternoon
this is the worst hill on the whole Route although Uncle Dan showed me places that were worse that he came down in 1850
camped on the Humbolt River just above gravelly ford.
traveled 20 miles.
Tuesday July 26th
Grass is very short, some Alkali in the bottom. there is a little lunch grass int he sandy upland amongst the sage brush that is very sweet and rich but hard to find camped on the River. traveled 20 miles.
Completed

102
Journal Across the plains in 1859
Friday July 22nd
10 miles to water only fit for cattle to drink
grazed our cattle and went 5 miles further and camped.
traveled 15 miles
Saturday July 23rd
We are still on what is called the mountain Road. Camped on a Creek near the Humbolt 
traveled 15 miles
Sunday July 24th
Layed over all day. Feed is very short, with herding our teams and standing guard at night we dont get enough sleep.
Completed

105
by J.A. Wilkinson
Saturday July 30th
More poor feed and bad water, the journey is getting monotonous and I wish it was over.
traveled 20 miles
Sunday July 31st
the River unclear is warm and nasty. Camped at a ford in the River.
traveled 15 miles
Monday Aug 1st
Captain Griffith and Evan Crane from Ottumwa Iowa have crossed the River and will either go over the mountains on the Truckie or the Honey Lake Route. Camped on the River 
traveled 20 miles
Completed

Journal  Across the plains in 1859  Wednesday July 24 Horace Greely passed our camp last night on the stage on his way to California. 10 miles to Spring where we fed at noon and 13 miles farther we found feed and water. traveled 23 miles  Thursday July 28  20 miles travel over a sandy road brought us to a big slough where we camped. water bad. traveled 20 miles  Friday July 29 same experience as yesterday cattle getting worn out traveled 20 miles
Completed

by J. A. Wilkinson Friday Aug 5  Traveled 30 miles last night and arrived at the Lake or the sink of the Humbolt at day light this Saturday morning. Traveled 6 miles around the Lake and camped water as salt as the sea traveled since yesterday morn 36 miles. Saturday Aug 6 Cutting grass with a scythe out in the lake and drying it for crossing the 40 mile Desert we have not had any real fresh water for 2 days and our stomachs are burning with salt and Alkali vinegar or Acid is the only thing that makes it drinkable.
Completed

106
Journal Across the plains in 1859
Tuesday Aug 2nd
Nothing but Alkali dust and sand and poor feed and water.
traveled 20 miles
Wednesday Aug 3rd
there is no grass on the River and we have to herd in the sage brush for bunch grass.
Camped on the River
traveled 20 miles
Thursday Aug 4th
This is a most God forsaken country
there is no game but sage rats an animal half the size of a common Rat. went 10 miles in the forenoon and grazed for a 30 mile desert
traveled 10 miles.
Completed

by J. A. Wilkinson  In 23 miles we come to some wells dug by some men to sell water to Emigrants. but is salt very few stock will drink it. we payed 25 cts a head to let our cattle drink but they refused it. we got all we wanted ourselves for nothing but it was no better than what we had. we got off the desert and Arrived at Ray Town at 8 o'clock this morning. Old Bally made the trip but died in an hour after drinking water Layed over all day had a mess of California potatoes and onions at 35 cts per pound we are camped on Carson River traveled since yesterday noon 40 miles
Completed

Journal  Across the plains in 1859  Sunday Aug 7  Loaded up our dry grass and started across the desert yesterday afternoon stopped at midnight and fed our dried grass and tried to eat some supper. there is not a thing that stock eat here and the road part of the way is Alkali and good but the rest of the way is deep sand. Chains and wagon Irons line the road from one end of the road to the other where they have been left by given out Emigrants since 1849 the wood has been burned by campers to cook with.
Completed

by J. A. Wilkinson Tuesday Aug 9  Overmans 2 wagons with Daugherty's and McGee's parted company with us and gone on ahead, while we with Cooper and the Norwegians are trying to recruit our teams when we can find grass. moved 5 miles up the river traveled 5 miles  Wednesday Aug 10  news has come to us that a great strike in silver and gold quartz mines on the East side of the Sierra Nevada mountains a short distance ahead of us has been found they call it Virginia City. went 20 miles up the river and camped  traveled 20 miles
Completed

Journal Across the plains in 1859  Monday Aug 8  Carson River like the Humboldt and Truckee sinks in this desert Basin and after getting to be Respectable Rivers from the many mountains Springs Brooks and Lakes they commence to sink in the sandy valley intil they are lost entirely in a shallow Lake becoming salt from continued evaporation. no game or Animals abound here, only the Turkey Buzzard and vulture living on dead cattle and Horses. when a steer has been dead a year he can be stood up on his feet, and looks natural as life moved 1 mile up the River and camped travelled 1 mile
Completed

by J. A. Wilkinson  Saturday Aug 13  Layed over all day and some of us  walked up to the mines again. there is considerable excitement here over what they call the comstock lead they have a tunnel run into the foot of mount Davidson about 100 feet and are taking out rock and grinding it with a mule in what they call an Arastra   Sunday Aug 14  went up to the mines again. Layed over all day. Overman and McGee had bought or traded some claims. Californians are arriving all the time and are taking up claims.
Completed

112
Journal Across the plains in 1859
Thursday Aug 11th
The country is very Sandy all along the Carson River but we find patches of very good feed with no Alkali, and good water in the River
Moved 10 miles up the River and camped about 6 miles East of the new mines called Virginia City
traveled 10 miles
Friday Aug 12
Layed over and went up on foot through a canyon to the new mining camp There is no Houses only cloth ones yet. We found our old comrades Overman and McGee up there
Completed

by J. A. Wilkinson  Tuesday Aug 16  Started again for California. Soon after starting this morning we came upon Irving Kimballs camp. He had left us on the Platte and went by Salt Lake. but by bad management he had lost a part of his Horses and the rest were hardly able to travel. he seemed very much disheartened. and remembered saying to me that he wouldn't see us any more after leaving us on the Platte. After going 12 miles and passing China Town we fed for an 18 mile drive without grass or water. Uncl Dan's big Brindle ox went into the River to day noon to drink and dropped dead. traveled 30 miles
Completed

Journal  Across the plains in 1859  Monday Aug 15  Layed over all day. went up to the mines again to day. Uncle Dan dont know any thing about quartz mines, and he is not in favor of staying. Overman and McGee have sent their teams over to California for Provisions. It seems that some Gold was found here several years ago and there is a camp of Chinese hear here working now. Virginia City is a hot dry rugged place with hardly a foot of level ground and not even fire wood to be had without some trouble Several of the Boys in Overmans crowd have taken up claims.
Completed

117
by J.A. Wilkinson
Thursday Aug 18th
the Sierra Nevada Range rises very abrupt on our right. Numerous mountain streams come down into the valley all along, that afford water power and Irrigation to the settlers but the most of them are dry at this time of the year.
We bought some fine mashanoek potatoes t day Raised int he sage brush land by Irrigation but they were 7 cents a pound
The wind blew a gale from the South to day so we could scarcely see for the dust. It blew a camp kettle off our Wagon Reach. Camped at the end of the valley
traveled 16 miles
Completed

116
Journal Across the plains in 1859
Wednesday Aug 17th
Passed through Washoe Valley yesterday afternoon and left Carson City on our Right 1/4 of a mile last evening after dark, and passed through Genoa to day
Carson Valley is an old settlement made by the mormons, but some of the mormons were called to Salt Lake 2 years ago during the disturbance with the United States
This part of the valley has some good land in it, and some of the sage brush sand raises good crops by Irrigation.
Saw some wheat in the stack and some that was not ripe that was raised by Irrigation.
traveled 20 miles
Completed

119
by J.A. Wilkinson
Saturday Aug 20th
Good feed in the valley but the most of it fenced up by settlers and cattle men.
We went over more mountains today covered with monstrous great Sugar Pines that look as though they would furnish a Lumber supply for a Hundred years
there is some frost at night but the days are quite warm
There are regular tamarack swamps here on the top of the mountains but the tamarack is different from that in michigan. Quails are different and they have grouse instead of Partridge
camped in the head of Lake Valley
traveled 7 miles
Completed

118
Journal Across the plains in 1859
Friday Aug 19th
Find that we are in the mouth of 6 mile Canyon where we turn off to cross the mountains.
I went back 5 miles to Recover the lost camp kettle last night
Our cattle got little or no feed last night
I took all day to get up the canyon. We met 2-6 mule teams loaded with goods for Virginia City but they had to double their teams to get over the bad places
Their mules are the largest I ever saw. they are driven with one line and all but the saddle mule have Bells. Camped in Hope Valley. traveled 6 miles
Completed

121
by J.A. Wilkinson
Monday Aug 22nd
Some Horse teams passed us to day that had crossed the South Platte with us and had gone by the way of Salt Lake. Their Horses were very weak and they were buying Barley at 5 cents per pound to feed them on. This is the first time I eve saw Barley fed to a Horse.
We have heard from the Sykes train that is ahead of us about a week Lorin or Dr Sykes as he was called had met with bad luck with his stock by rushing them along too fast, and many had died
passed through Strawberry Valley
traveled 15 miles
Completed

120
Journal Across the Plains in 1859
Sunday Aug 21st
went over another summit today and crossed what is called the state line into California. 
we are on the head of the American River.
Came across Mr Daugherty working in a Logging Vamp. He had left us at Rag-town. he is getting good wages with his oxen hauling Logs. 
this would be a delightful place to camp. only there is no feed that our cattle will eat. there is some Hay for sale at the Public Houses at 5 cents per pound. 
Camped in the mountains. traveled 15 miles.
Completed

122
Journal Across the plains in 1859
Tuesday Aug 23rd
We Arrive to day at Hanks Corners a short distance South of Placerville of Hang-Town as it has always been familliarly known and our journey is at an end.
traveled 15 miles
We have been 169 days on the Road from Dowagiae Michigan and have traveled 2516 miles
2 of our oxen that we left Michigan with out of 6 got through
Hiram Spencer got through with 3 oxen and a cow
David C Broderick shot Sept 13 & died Sept 16th
Completed
Cover of journal without any writing
Completed

Cover
Journal Across the Plains in 1859
By J.A. Wilkinson
